questions.text: SCF (Supply Chain Finance) is mainly about improving cashflow across buyers and suppliers by using trade events like invoices and approvals.
questions.answer: True. SCF improves working capital by using commercial events (POs, invoices, approvals, delivery) to let suppliers get paid earlier and/or buyers pay later with financing in between.

questions.text: Reverse factoring is buyer-led: once the buyer approves an invoice, a financier can pay the supplier early and get repaid by the buyer later.
questions.answer: True. Reverse factoring is typically initiated by the buyer; the approved invoice becomes the basis for a financier to advance funds to the supplier, then collect from the buyer at maturity.

questions.text: In reverse factoring, the buyer usually pays earlier than normal because the supplier is paid early.
questions.answer: False. The supplier is paid early by the financier; the buyer usually pays the financier at the original (or negotiated) maturity date, not earlier.

questions.text: The invoice approval step is a key gate, because it changes an invoice from 'a supplier claim' into 'an approved payable' the buyer acknowledges.
questions.answer: True. Approval converts the invoice into an acknowledged obligation, reducing dispute risk and making it financeable at better terms.

questions.text: Paper-based invoice workflows mostly fail because PDFs are impossible to store digitally.
questions.answer: False. PDFs can be stored; the issue is manual processing, inconsistent data, slow approvals, weak traceability, and error/fraud risk.

questions.text: A big real-world problem in SCF is that different parties often have different 'versions of truth' about invoice status.
questions.answer: True. Buyer, supplier, and financier often rely on separate systems and timestamps, causing disputes and reconciliation work over what the current status actually is.

questions.text: A shared ledger can reduce reconciliation work by giving all parties the same view of invoice state transitions.
questions.answer: True. If state transitions are recorded consistently and shared, parties spend less time reconciling mismatched records and more time executing the workflow.

questions.text: Immutability means mistakes can never be corrected in the system.
questions.answer: False. Immutability means past records aren’t overwritten; corrections are made by appending compensating events (e.g., cancel/reissue, adjustment) with traceable history.

questions.text: Smart contracts are mainly useful because they force the allowed sequence of steps (e.g., you can't fund before approval).
questions.answer: True. Smart contracts can enforce a state machine and permissions so invalid transitions (like funding an unapproved invoice) are rejected by code.

questions.text: Blockchains automatically make real-world inputs (like delivery confirmation) true and trustworthy.
questions.answer: False. Blockchains preserve what was submitted; they don’t verify the real world. Trust depends on integrations/oracles, controls, and evidence quality.

questions.text: An oracle / integration feed is often the weakest link, because it can inject wrong data into an otherwise 'correct' ledger.
questions.answer: True. If the integration submits incorrect or spoofed events, the ledger can faithfully record bad data; verification and controls around inputs are critical.

questions.text: Storing a hash of a document on-chain proves the document is accurate about the real world.
questions.answer: False. A hash proves integrity (the document hasn’t changed since hashing), not that the content is truthful or corresponds to reality.

questions.text: A minimal SCF invoice state machine can be: Created → Approved → FinancingRequested → Funded → Settled.
questions.answer: True. That’s a common minimal lifecycle for invoice-based financing workflows, though real systems may add states like Rejected, Cancelled, Disputed, or PartiallySettled.

questions.text: A good state machine prevents invalid jumps like Created → Funded without approval.
questions.answer: True. Valid transitions constrain the workflow so each step has required prerequisites and produces an auditable sequence.

questions.text: Access control is optional because the chain is already secure.
questions.answer: False. Chain security doesn’t replace application authorization. You still must restrict who can create, approve, request financing, fund, or settle.

questions.text: In most designs, only the buyer (or their delegated approver) should be allowed to approve invoices.
questions.answer: True. Approval is the buyer’s attestation that goods/services are accepted and payable; suppliers or financiers should not self-approve.

questions.text: Letting the financier approve invoices is usually fine because they are the ones taking risk.
questions.answer: False. The buyer is the party that owes payment; financier risk assessment should not replace buyer acceptance/approval, otherwise incentives and disputes get messy fast.

questions.text: On-chain data should usually be minimal: identifiers, state, timestamps, hashes/pointers, and permissions.
questions.answer: True. Enterprise designs often keep sensitive payloads off-chain and put only what’s needed for coordination, auditability, and integrity on-chain.

questions.text: Putting full invoice PDFs and sensitive commercial terms on-chain is usually a good idea in enterprise SCF.
questions.answer: False. It creates privacy, confidentiality, and compliance risks. Typically you store references/hashes and keep the full documents off-chain with controlled access.

questions.text: Integrations usually include ERP (invoice creation), logistics (delivery proof), and banking (payment settlement).
questions.answer: True. Those three systems usually generate the key events the workflow depends on: invoice issuance/approval, delivery acceptance, and payment confirmation.

questions.text: Payment settlement is usually off-chain (bank rails), even if invoice state is tracked on-chain.
questions.answer: True. In most enterprise settings, final money movement happens through bank rails; the chain records state and evidence, not the actual fiat transfer.

questions.text: ISO 20022 is mainly about richer structured payment data that helps matching and reconciliation.
questions.answer: True. ISO 20022 enables more structured fields and references in payment messages, improving automation and reducing reconciliation ambiguity.

questions.text: E-invoicing trends matter because they standardize invoice data and reduce ambiguity and manual work.
questions.answer: True. Standard formats and validation rules turn invoices into consistent data objects, which reduces manual keying, mismatches, and disputes.

questions.text: The biggest driver of financing cost is always pure credit risk; operational friction never matters.
questions.answer: False. Operational friction (uncertain status, disputes, verification costs, manual handling) can materially increase cost and delay—even when credit risk is stable.

questions.text: A shared system can reduce some fraud types, like duplicate invoice submission inside the network.
questions.answer: True. Shared identifiers and a single lifecycle can prevent or detect re-use of the same invoice within the network (though not all fraud types).

questions.text: A shared ledger completely prevents collusion between a buyer and supplier.
questions.answer: False. A ledger helps detect inconsistencies but cannot prevent intentional collusion; governance, audits, and independent verification are still needed.

questions.text: A token is required for a blockchain-based workflow to function in an enterprise setting.
questions.answer: False. Enterprise workflows can run on permissioned or public chains without native incentives; utility comes from shared state, auditability, and automation.

questions.text: Token incentives can create perverse behavior, like encouraging spammy invoices to farm rewards.
questions.answer: True. If rewards track proxy metrics (volume, activity), participants may optimize for the metric rather than real business value—classic cobra effect.

questions.text: Utility-first design focuses on shared state, auditability, and automation, not speculation.
questions.answer: True. The primary goal is operational correctness and coordination; tokens (if any) are secondary and should not be required for basic workflow utility.

questions.text: If a system only works when the token price goes up, it's probably not robust system design.
questions.answer: True. A system dependent on speculative appreciation is fragile; robust systems still work when incentives cool or market conditions change.

questions.text: In reverse factoring, is buyer invoice approval the key step that makes financing cheaper and reduces dispute risk?
questions.answer: Yes. Buyer approval is the attestation that the invoice is valid and payable, reducing uncertainty and enabling better financing terms.

questions.text: Does a 'single source of truth' mean all parties (buyer, supplier, financier) share the same authoritative invoice state and timestamps instead of reconciling separate records?
questions.answer: Yes. It means there is one authoritative lifecycle record used by all parties, reducing disputes and reconciliation workload.

questions.text: Does 'immutability' still allow corrections by adding new events (like cancellation/adjustment) rather than rewriting history?
questions.answer: Yes. You correct by appending compensating actions with traceability, not by erasing or overwriting past entries.

questions.text: Are integrations/oracles a major risk because they can inject wrong or spoofed real-world events into an otherwise tamper-evident ledger?
questions.answer: Yes. If the input source lies or is compromised, the ledger can record bad data perfectly; controls and verification around inputs are essential.

questions.text: Should sensitive invoice documents and commercial terms usually stay off-chain, with only IDs, states, timestamps, and hashes/pointers stored on-chain?
questions.answer: Yes. Keeping sensitive payloads off-chain reduces confidentiality and compliance risks while still enabling integrity and coordination via hashes/pointers.

questions.text: Is 'finance the same invoice twice' (duplicate financing) a realistic abuse case that needs mitigations like unique invoice IDs and shared status tracking?
questions.answer: Yes. Duplicate financing is a known risk; shared lifecycle status and unique identifiers help prevent or detect it within a participant network.

questions.text: Do you still need access control in a tamper-evident system, because integrity doesn't decide who is allowed to approve, fund, or settle?
questions.answer: Yes. Tamper-evidence doesn't equal authorization; you must explicitly restrict who can perform each state transition.

questions.text: Is settlement confirmation hard mainly because bank rails, references, and timing can be messy, and it improves when payments carry clean structured identifiers (e.g., ISO 20022 references)?
questions.answer: Yes. Matching payments to invoices is often the bottleneck; structured references and consistent identifiers reduce ambiguity and manual reconciliation.

questions.text: Can tokenomics be dangerous in corporate workflows because people optimize for reward metrics (activity/volume) rather than real operational value?
questions.answer: Yes. Incentives tied to proxy metrics can drive gaming behavior (cobra effect), creating spam or distorted workflows that look active but add no value.

questions.text: Would improving any one layer first (ERP, logistics proof, bank confirmation, or ledger) be a defensible strategy depending on which bottleneck causes the most delays and disputes?
questions.answer: Yes. The highest-leverage layer varies by context; you pick the bottleneck that dominates cycle time, dispute rate, or reconciliation cost in the current process.
